prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the post is in the wrong. The situation is about a hairdresser who didn't get the color right. The author showed a reference picture for a light brown rose gold, emphasized wanting more brown than red, and even mentioned they were okay without the rose tint. Their hair was bleach blonde to start with. The result was redder than they wanted.

The author argues that they shouldn't have to pay again because the hairdresser didn't meet the request. They showed the picture multiple times. The hairdresser offered to fix it for free. The user initially thinks the author is in the wrong but wants to know others' opinions.

Hmm. First, the key points are communication and expectations. The client clearly communicated their desired color, provided a reference, and highlighted wanting light brown with more brown than red. The hairdresser may have misinterpreted or not followed the instructions correctly. Since it's the hairdresser's job to achieve the desired result, especially when a reference is provided, it's their responsibility to ensure it's correct. If the color is significantly different (more red than brown), that's a mistake on their part. Therefore, the client shouldn't have to pay for a correction. So the answer would be B (No, the author isn't in the wrong).
